<script type="text/javascript">
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
	if(container_q != '' && container_q != null){	    
	    sessionStorage.setItem('container',container_q);
	    	    location.href = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/gleaming-pisces-applejeus-poolrat-and-pondrat';
	}
</script>

	<title>Gleaming Pisces Poisoned Python Packages Campaign Delivers PondRAT Linux and MacOS Backdoors</title>
	<meta name="description" content="We track a campaign by Gleaming Pisces (Citrine Sleet) delivering Linux or macOS backdoors via Python packages, aiming to infiltrate supply chain vendors. We track a campaign by Gleaming Pisces (Citrine Sleet) delivering Linux or macOS backdoors via Python packages, aiming to infiltrate supply chain vendors." />

	<meta property="og:title" content="Gleaming Pisces Poisoned Python Packages Campaign Delivers PondRAT Linux and MacOS Backdoors" />
	<meta property="og:description" content="We track a campaign by Gleaming Pisces (Citrine Sleet) delivering Linux or macOS backdoors via Python packages, aiming to infiltrate supply chain vendors. We track a campaign by Gleaming Pisces (Citrine Sleet) delivering Linux or macOS backdoors via Python packages, aiming to infiltrate supply chain vendors." />

<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Yoav Zemah"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>
<meta name="post_tags" content="AppleJeus,Citrine Sleet,Cryptocurrency,Gleaming Pisces,Linux,macOS,North Korea,PondRAT,POOLRAT,Python,remote administration tool (RAT),supply chain"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Gleaming Pisces Poisoned Python Packages Campaign Delivers PondRAT Linux and MacOS Backdoors","name":"Gleaming Pisces Poisoned Python Packages Campaign Delivers PondRAT Linux and MacOS Backdoors","description":"We track a campaign by Gleaming Pisces (Citrine Sleet) delivering Linux or macOS backdoors via Python packages, aiming to infiltrate supply chain vendors.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/gleaming-pisces-applejeus-poolrat-and-pondrat\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/gleaming-pisces-applejeus-poolrat-and-pondrat\/","datePublished":"September 18, 2024","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nUnit 42 researchers have been tracking the activity of an ongoing poisoned Python packages campaign delivering Linux and macOS backdoors via infected Python software packages. We\u2019ve named these infected software packages PondRAT. We\u2019ve also found Linux variants of POOLRAT, a known macOS remote administration tool (RAT) previously attributed to Gleaming Pisces (aka Citrine Sleet, distributor of AppleJeus). Based on our research into both RAT families, we assess that the new PondRAT is a lighter version of POOLRAT.\r\n\r\nThe attackers behind this campaign uploaded several poisoned Python packages to PyPI, a popular repository of open-source Python packages. We assess with medium confidence that this activity is linked to Gleaming Pisces based on noticeable code similarities, and on previous public research and attribution.\r\n\r\nWe assess that the threat actor\u2019s objective was to secure access to supply chain vendors through developers\u2019 endpoints and subsequently gain access to the vendors' customers' endpoints, as observed in previous incidents. A successful installation of third-party packages can result in malware infection, compromising organizations that rely on the popular PyPI repository.\r\n\r\nAt the time of writing this article, it appears that the PyPI administrators have removed all the poisoned packages referenced in this article.\r\n\r\nThrough the detection and intelligence provided by Advanced WildFire, Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected against PondRAT and POOLRAT through the following products:\r\n\r\n \tCortex XDR with Advanced WildFire can help detect new variants of PondRAT and POOLRAT and prevent their attack chains.\r\n \tNext-Generation Firewalls with Cloud-Delivered Security Services, including Advanced WildFire detection, Advanced URL Filtering and DNS Security categorize known command and control (C2) domains and IP addresses as malicious.\r\n \tOrganizations can also engage the Unit 42 Incident Response team to help with a compromise or to provide a proactive assessment to lower your risk.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nPython, North Korea\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nGleaming Pisces Overview\r\nGleaming Pisces (aka Citrine Sleet, distributor of AppleJeus) is a financially motivated threat actor affiliated with North Korea that has been active since at least 2018. This group is closely linked to North Korea's Reconnaissance General Bureau (RGB) and is known for its sophisticated attacks, particularly against the cryptocurrency industry.\r\n\r\nGleaming Pisces gained notoriety for past campaigns where the group deployed fake cryptocurrency trading software to infiltrate and compromise systems across various platforms.\r\nThe Connection to Known Gleaming Pisces Malware\r\nDuring our investigation of the poisoned Python packages campaign described in this writeup, we analyzed the Linux RAT that was delivered as its final payload. We discovered significant similarities with macOS malware used in a previous AppleJeus campaign reported by CISA, orchestrated by the Gleaming Pisces threat actor.\r\n\r\nThe following similarities indicate a shared codebase:\r\n\r\n \tOverlapping code structures\r\n \tIdentical function names and encryption keys\r\n \tSimilar execution flows\r\n\r\nWe named this RAT family PondRAT. Further analysis revealed that PondRAT shared many characteristics with POOLRAT, another known macOS RAT in the arsenal of Gleaming Pisces. Based on these findings, we attribute the poisoned Python packages campaign to Gleaming Pisces.\r\nPoisoned Python Packages Campaign Technical Analysis and Detection\r\nWhile tracking down recent activity by Gleaming Pisces, we came across poisoned Python packages that various malicious fake personas uploaded to PyPI. These poisoned packages implemented an evasive infection chain to avoid detection and eventually downloaded a Linux RAT onto the infected endpoints. VIPYR Security and Qihoo 360 reported on this activity in detail, specifically involving the following Python packages:\r\n\r\n \treal-ids (versions 0.0.3 - 0.0.5)\r\n \tcoloredtxt (version 0.0.2)\r\n \tbeautifultext (version 0.0.1)\r\n \tminisound (version 0.0.2)\r\n\r\nOur analysis determined that while Qihoo 360 also reported on Windows-related activities, those activities appear to be separate from the Linux and macOS campaigns. Further, we assess that the activity reported on by Qihoo 360 was performed by a different threat actor, in contrast to the Linux and macOS campaigns that we here connect to Gleaming Pisces.\r\n\r\nThe infection chain includes several poisoned Python packages that decode and execute encoded code. After Python installed and loaded the malicious package, a malicious piece of code eventually ran several bash commands to download the RAT, modifying its permissions and executing it.\r\n\r\nFigure 1 below shows the infection chain and the prevention of PondRAT by Cortex XDR.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136764\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 1. The PondRAT malware prevented by Cortex XDR.[\/caption]\r\nComparing PondRAT to Previous Gleaming Pisces Attributed Malware\r\nWe found other malware by pivoting based on code similarities to PondRAT, as well as to previously conducted research and attribution to Gleaming Pisces. Figure 2 below depicts a summary of these similarities.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136766\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 2. Similarities between the malware we found and other malware previously attributed to Gleaming Pisces.[\/caption]\r\nCode Similarities between PondRAT and Kupayupdate_stage2\r\nIn their recently published research, VIPYR Security analyzed the code of a Linux RAT (SHA256: 973f7939ea03fd2c9663dafc21bb968f56ed1b9a56b0284acf73c3ee141c053c) that was an unknown at the time, which we now identify as the Linux variant of PondRAT. Gleaming Pisces\u2019 operators did not strip the code, meaning the function names remained as the threat actor initially named them.\r\n\r\nWhen we examined this RAT's main function, we saw that it contained calls to two different functions: FConnectProxy and AcceptRequest:\r\n\r\n \tFConnectProxy: This function handles the connection to the C2 server. It sets up the URI and parameters of the HTTP requests.\r\n \tAcceptRequest: This function parses and decrypts commands from the C2 server and is responsible for receiving and executing commands from their remote operators.\r\n\r\nBack in 2021, CISA reported about another AppleJeus attack wave called Kupay Wallet. CISA identified a macOS RAT named kupayupdate_stage2 (SHA256: 91eaf215be336eae983d069de16630cc3580e222c427f785e0da312d0692d0fd) that was used as the final payload of this wave.\r\n\r\nUpon analyzing the kupayupdate_stage2 RAT for macOS, we noticed that the malware\u2019s functions were also not stripped. When examining its code, we observed several similarities to the Linux RAT. This included the function names FConnectProxy and AcceptRequest, and similar code execution flow.\r\n\r\nFigure 3 shows these similarities below.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136768\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"900\"] Figure 3. Method names and execution flow similarities of the new Linux RAT and kupayupdate_stage2 RAT.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe next step in our analysis was comparing both of the RATs' AcceptRequest functions. We noticed both variants use the same command numerical IDs and similar method names.\r\n\r\nFigure 4 below shows that these functions are almost identical, including the command numerical IDs.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136770\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"600\"] Figure 4. Comparison of both RATs\u2019 AcceptRequest function.[\/caption]\r\nShared Encryption Key\r\nWhile looking into the encryption method of PondRAT, we noticed that the key used for encrypting output sent back to the server was the following string:\r\n\r\n \twLqfM]%wTx`~tUTbw&gt;R^#yG5R(3C:;.\r\n\r\nWhen we compared this key to the one used by kupayupdate_stage2, we noticed it was the same. Figure 5 shows the shared key below.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136772\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"857\"] Figure 5. kupayupdate_stage2 encryption key.[\/caption]\r\nPondRAT MacOS Variants Analysis\r\nFollowing the aforementioned findings, we pivoted and retrieved additional samples of PondRAT\u2019s macOS variant that shared the same encryption key. We found a macOS sample that was previously attributed to be a part of the poisoned Python packages campaign and an additional AppleJeus-related macOS RAT.\r\nos_helper\r\nAfter analyzing the additional macOS samples that shared the same encryption key, we noticed that one of the samples, a Mach-O multi-arch binary file (SHA256: bfd74b4a1b413fa785a49ca4a9c0594441a3e01983fc7f86125376fdbd4acf6b), was using the same infrastructure as the Linux variant of PondRAT.\r\n\r\nSince multi-arch binary files for macOS support both Intel and ARM architectures, this sample contained two other Mach-O binaries. These were compiled for x64 and ARM accordingly, as expected.\r\n\r\nThe two dropped binaries share the same code (function names and encryption key) with kupayupdate_stage2 as the Linux variant of PondRAT. Based on the apparent code similarities and the shared submitted name os_helper, we assess it was also delivered as the final poisoned Python packages campaign payload. Additionally, these macOS variants used the same C2 (jdkgradle[.]com) as the Linux variant.\r\n\r\nFigure 6 below depicts how Cortex XDR prevented the macOS malware execution.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136774\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"500\"] Figure 6. The execution of the os_helper macOS malware prevented by Cortex XDR.[\/caption]\r\nAppleJeus-Related MacOS Variant\r\nAnother macOS sample (SHA256: cbf4cfa2d3c3fb04fe349161e051a8cf9b6a29f8af0c3d93db953e5b5dc39c86) we found during pivoting that shared the same encryption key was configured to use rebelthumb[.]net as the C2 server. Volexity reported that this domain was part of the AppleJeus campaign back in 2022. This finding further strengthens our attribution of this campaign to Gleaming Pisces.\r\nThe Connection between PondRAT and Gleaming Pisces\u2019 POOLRAT\r\nDuring our analysis, we found one more difference between the two PondRAT Linux and macOS variants, aside from being compiled for different OS types. The Linux variant implemented a new SendPost function by using the libcurl library while using the file path \/tmp\/xweb_log.md as the error log for failed connection attempts to the C2 server.\r\n\r\nSearching for files with similar behavior, we identified two more relevant samples that belonged to a Linux RAT exhibiting this trait. We identified this RAT as the Linux variant of POOLRAT.\r\nWhat Is POOLRAT?\r\nIn a 2021 report, CISA identified a macOS RAT dubbed prtspool (SHA256: 5e40d106977017b1ed235419b1e59ff090e1f43ac57da1bb5d80d66ae53b1df8), used as the final payload in one of the AppleJeus (CoinGoTrade) attack waves. Mandiant's analysis of the 3CX supply chain attack also mentioned this RAT family. They reported that attackers used the POOLRAT malware to compromise 3CX\u2019s macOS build environment.\r\n\r\nESET has also identified similarities between POOLRAT and a backdoor called BADCALL for Linux, also attributed to Gleaming Pisces. Figure 7 below shows the execution prevention of the POOLRAT macOS backdoor.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136776\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"500\"] Figure 7. The execution of the POOLRAT macOS malware prevented by Cortex XDR.[\/caption]\r\nThe Linux Variants of POOLRAT\r\nThe newly discovered Linux variants of POOLRAT (SHA256: 5c907b722c53a5be256dc5f96b755bc9e0b032cc30973a52d984d4174bace456, SHA256: f3b0da965a4050ab00fce727bb31e0f889a9c05d68d777a8068cfc15a71d3703) exhibit several notable similarities to its macOS counterpart (prtspool). According to our analysis, we conclude that they are variants of the macOS POOLRAT rather than a new piece of malware.\r\n\r\nThe Linux and macOS versions use an identical function structure for loading their configurations, featuring similar method names and functionality. Additionally, the method names in both variants are strikingly similar, and the strings are almost identical. Lastly, the mechanism that handles commands from the C2 is nearly identical.\r\n\r\nFigure 8 compares the LoadConfig method of POOLRAT\u2019s macOS and Linux variants.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136778\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"700\"] Figure 8. Comparison of the LoadConfig function between POOLRAT for macOS and POOLRAT for Linux.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThese similarities in configuration and command handling suggest that the Linux versions are adaptations of the original macOS malware, justifying their classification as variants of POOLRAT.\r\n\r\nFigure 9 below compares the main functionality of both of the variants.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_136780\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"554\"] Figure 9. Comparison between POOLRAT for macOS and POOLRAT for Linux.[\/caption]\r\nPondRAT: The Lighter Version of POOLRAT\r\nWhen analyzing PondRAT samples, we found that the command handler had similarities to POOLRAT.\r\n\r\nPondRAT has a straightforward set of commands that give the attacker the following capabilities:\r\n\r\n \tUploading and downloading files\r\n \tChecking an implant\u2019s status to confirm if it is active\r\n \tInstructing the implant to pause operations for a specified duration (\u201csleep\u201d)\r\n \tExecuting commands (with an option to either retrieve their output or not)\r\n\r\nAs the functionality of PondRAT is similar yet more limited than POOLRAT, we assess that PondRAT is a lighter version of POOLRAT. Table 1 below compares the commands implemented in POOLRAT and PondRAT.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nPOOLRAT Commands\r\nPondRAT Commands\r\nDescription\r\n\r\n\r\nMSG_Up\r\nMsgUp\r\nDownload a file from the C2 server.\r\n\r\n\r\nMSG_Down\r\nMsgDown\r\nUpload a file to the C2 Server.\r\n\r\n\r\nMSG_Cmd\r\nMsgCmd\r\nExecute a command and retrieve the output.\r\n\r\n\r\nMSG_Run\r\nMsgRun\r\nExecute a command and don\u2019t retrieve the output.\r\n\r\n\r\nMSG_ReadConfig\r\n\r\nRead the configuration file and send it to the C2.\r\n\r\n\r\nMSG_WriteConfig\r\n\r\nWrite a new configuration file.\r\n\r\n\r\nMSG_SecureDel\r\n\r\nDelete a file.\r\n\r\n\r\nMSG_Dir\r\n\r\nList a directory.\r\n\r\n\r\nMSG_Test\r\n\r\nAttempt to connect to an IPv4 address.\u00a0\r\n\r\n\r\nMSG_SetPath\r\n\r\nChange the current working directory.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 1. Comparison between POOLRAT and PondRAT commands.\r\nConclusion\r\nWe\u2019ve examined the poisoned Python packages campaign and its ties to the North Korean Gleaming Pisces APT group. Our analysis of the Linux variant of PondRAT, which was dropped as the final payload in this campaign, revealed significant similarities to malware attributed to Gleaming Pisces (kupayupdate_stage2).\r\n\r\nFurthermore, our investigation uncovered that PondRAT shares code similarities with POOLRAT, malware that was also previously attributed to Gleaming Pisces. The evidence of additional Linux variants of POOLRAT showed that Gleaming Pisces has been enhancing its capabilities across both Linux and macOS platforms.\r\n\r\nThe weaponization of legitimate-looking Python packages across multiple operating systems poses a significant risk to organizations. Such attacks pose a great risk because they can easily remain under the radar and pose detection challenges. Successful installation of malicious third-party packages can result in malware infection that compromises an entire network.\r\nProtections and Mitigations\r\nFor Palo Alto Networks customers, our products and services provide the following coverage associated with this group.\r\n\r\nCortex XDR and XSIAM help detect user and credential-based threats by analyzing user activity from multiple data sources, including the following:\r\n\r\n \tEndpoints\r\n \tNetwork firewalls\r\n \tActive Directory\r\n \tIdentity and access management solutions\r\n \tCloud workloads\r\n\r\nCortex XDR and XSIAM build behavioral profiles of user activity over time with machine learning. By comparing new activity to past activity, peer activity and the expected behavior of the entity, Cortex XDR and XSIAM help detect anomalous activity indicative of credential-based attacks.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks also offers the following protections related to the attacks discussed in this post:\r\n\r\n \tHelps prevent the execution of known malicious malware and execution of unknown malware by using Behavioral Threat Protection and machine learning based on the Local Analysis module.\r\n \tCortex XDR Pro and XSIAM help detect post-exploit activity, including credential-based attacks, with behavioral analytics.\r\n \tNext-Generation Firewall with the Advanced Threat Prevention security subscription can help block the malware C2 traffic via the following Threat Prevention signature: 86805.\r\n \tThe Advanced WildFire machine learning models and analysis techniques have been reviewed and updated in light of these new PondRAT and POOLRAT variants. Multiple products in the Palo Alto Networks portfolio leverage Advanced WildFire to provide coverage against both PondRAT and POOLRAT variants and other threats.\r\n\r\nIf you think you might have been impacted or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the Unit 42 Incident Response team or call:\r\n\r\n \tNorth America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)\r\n \tEMEA: +31.20.299.3130\r\n \tAPAC: +65.6983.8730\r\n \tJapan: +81.50.1790.0200\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks has shared these findings, including file samples and indicators of compromise, with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the Cyber Threat Alliance.\r\nAdditional Resources\r\n\r\n \tThreat Assessment: North Korean Threat Groups \u2013 Unit 42, Palo Alto Networks\r\n\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\nPondRAT Linux variant\r\n\r\n \t973f7939ea03fd2c9663dafc21bb968f56ed1b9a56b0284acf73c3ee141c053c\r\n\r\nPondRAT macOS variant\r\n\r\n \t0b5db31e47b0dccfdec46e74c0e70c6a1684768dbacc9eacbb4fd2ef851994c7\r\n \t3c8dbfcbb4fccbaf924f9a650a04cb4715f4a58d51ef49cc75bfcef0ac258a3e\r\n \tbce1eb513aaac344b5b8f7a9ba9c9e36fc89926d327ee5cc095fb4a895a12f80\r\n \tbfd74b4a1b413fa785a49ca4a9c0594441a3e01983fc7f86125376fdbd4acf6b\r\n \tcbf4cfa2d3c3fb04fe349161e051a8cf9b6a29f8af0c3d93db953e5b5dc39c86\r\n\r\nPondRAT C2s\r\n\r\n \tjdkgradle[.]com\r\n \trebelthumb[.]net\r\n\r\nPOOLRAT Linux variant\r\n\r\n \tf3b0da965a4050ab00fce727bb31e0f889a9c05d68d777a8068cfc15a71d3703\r\n \t5c907b722c53a5be256dc5f96b755bc9e0b032cc30973a52d984d4174bace456\r\n\r\nPOOLRAT C2s\r\n\r\n \twww.talesseries[.]com\/write.php\r\n \trgedist[.]com\/sfxl.php\r\n","publisher":{"@type":"Organization","@id":"#panworg"},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/06\/word-image-449925-135181-16-300x300.png","width":300,"height":300},"speakable":{"@type":"SpeakableSpecification","xPath":["\/html\/head\/title","\/html\/head\/meta[@name='description']\/@content"]},"author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Yoav Zemah"}]}</script><link rel='stylesheet' id='crayon-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/crayon-syntax-highlighter/css/min/crayon.min.css?ver=_2.7.2_beta' media='all' />

<script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

  <div class="container px-sm-30">
    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>

<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">

<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Cortex' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            referer = 'Cortex' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();        
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/citrine-sleet/">Citrine Sleet</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="gleaming-pisces-applejeus-poolrat-and-pondrat:hero:Cryptocurrency" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/cryptocurrency/">Cryptocurrency</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="gleaming-pisces-applejeus-poolrat-and-pondrat:hero:Gleaming Pisces" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/gleaming-pisces/">Gleaming Pisces</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="gleaming-pisces-applejeus-poolrat-and-pondrat:hero:Linux" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/linux/">Linux</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="gleaming-pisces-applejeus-poolrat-and-pondrat:hero:macOS" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/macos/">MacOS</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="gleaming-pisces-applejeus-poolrat-and-pondrat:hero:North Korea" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/north-korea/">North Korea</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="gleaming-pisces-applejeus-poolrat-and-pondrat:hero:PondRAT" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/pondrat/">PondRAT</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="gleaming-pisces-applejeus-poolrat-and-pondrat:hero:POOLRAT" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/poolrat/">POOLRAT</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="gleaming-pisces-applejeus-poolrat-and-pondrat:hero:Python" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/python/">Python</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="gleaming-pisces-applejeus-poolrat-and-pondrat:hero:remote administration tool (RAT)" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/remote-administration-tool-rat/">Remote administration tool (RAT)</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="gleaming-pisces-applejeus-poolrat-and-pondrat:hero:supply chain" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/supply-chain/">Supply chain</a></li></ul></div>
		</li>                </ul>
                <div class="ab__options">
                  <ul role="list">
                                        <li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/gleaming-pisces-applejeus-poolrat-and-pondrat/?pdf=download&#038;lg=en&#038;_wpnonce=dcff69efdc" role="link" target="_blank"  title="Click here to download" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="gleaming-pisces-applejeus-poolrat-and-pondrat:hero:pdfdownload"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-download.svg" alt="Download Icon"></a></li>
                    <li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/gleaming-pisces-applejeus-poolrat-and-pondrat/?pdf=print&#038;lg=en&#038;_wpnonce=dcff69efdc" target="_blank" role="link" title="Click here to print" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="gleaming-pisces-applejeus-poolrat-and-pondrat:hero:pdfprint"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-print.svg" alt="Print Icon"></a></li>
                  </ul>
                  
	<div class="ab__share" id="shareDropdown" role="button" aria-expanded="false">

    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-136761-_xw19ouqh7ayq"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>Unit 42 researchers have been tracking the activity of an ongoing poisoned Python packages campaign delivering Linux and macOS backdoors via infected Python software packages. We’ve named these infected software packages PondRAT. We’ve also found Linux variants of POOLRAT, a known macOS remote administration tool (RAT) previously attributed to Gleaming Pisces (aka Citrine Sleet, distributor of AppleJeus). Based on our research into both RAT families, we assess that <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/threat-assessment-north-korean-threat-groups-2024/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the new PondRAT</a> is a lighter version of POOLRAT.</p>
<p>The attackers behind this campaign uploaded several poisoned Python packages to PyPI, a popular repository of open-source Python packages. We assess with medium confidence that this activity is linked to Gleaming Pisces based on noticeable code similarities, and on previous public research and attribution.</p>
<p>We assess that the threat actor’s objective was to secure access to supply chain vendors through developers’ endpoints and subsequently gain access to the vendors' customers' endpoints, as observed in previous incidents. A successful installation of third-party packages can result in malware infection, compromising organizations that rely on the popular PyPI repository.</p>
<p>At the time of writing this article, it appears that the PyPI administrators have removed all the poisoned packages referenced in this article.</p>
<p>Through the detection and intelligence provided by <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>Advanced WildFire</strong></a>, Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected against PondRAT and POOLRAT through the following products:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XDR" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>Cortex XDR</strong></a> with <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>Advanced WildFire</strong></a> can help detect new variants of <strong>PondRAT</strong> and <strong>POOLRAT</strong> and prevent their attack chains.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>Next-Generation Firewalls</strong></a> with <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/security-subscriptions" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>Cloud-Delivered Security Services</strong></a>, including Advanced WildFire detection, <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>Advanced URL Filtering</strong></a> and <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>DNS Security</strong></a> categorize known command and control (C2) domains and IP addresses as malicious.</li>
<li>Organizations can also engage the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>Unit 42 Incident Response team</strong></a> to help with a compromise or to provide a proactive assessment to lower your risk.</li>
</ul>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/python/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Python</b></a>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/north-korea/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">North Korea</a></strong></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-136761-_t0p9rgmqno95"></a>Gleaming Pisces Overview</h2>
<p>Gleaming Pisces (aka Citrine Sleet, distributor of AppleJeus) is a financially motivated <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/threat-assessment-north-korean-threat-groups-2024/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">threat actor affiliated with North Korea</a> that has been active since at least 2018. This group is closely linked to North Korea's Reconnaissance General Bureau (RGB) and is known for its sophisticated attacks, particularly against the cryptocurrency industry.</p>
<p>Gleaming Pisces gained notoriety for past campaigns where the group deployed fake cryptocurrency trading software to infiltrate and compromise systems across various platforms.</p>
<h2><a id="post-136761-_knht3jxoglz9"></a>The Connection to Known Gleaming Pisces Malware</h2>
<p>During our investigation of the poisoned Python packages campaign described in this writeup, we analyzed the Linux RAT that was delivered as its final payload. We discovered significant similarities with macOS malware used in a previous <a href="https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/analysis-reports/ar21-048e" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AppleJeus</a> campaign reported by CISA, orchestrated by the Gleaming Pisces threat actor.</p>
<p>The following similarities indicate a shared codebase:</p>
<ul>
<li>Overlapping code structures</li>
<li>Identical function names and encryption keys</li>
<li>Similar execution flows</li>
</ul>
<p>We named this RAT family PondRAT. Further analysis revealed that PondRAT shared many characteristics with <a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/osx.poolrat" target="_blank" rel="noopener">POOLRAT</a>, another known macOS RAT in the arsenal of Gleaming Pisces. Based on these findings, we attribute the poisoned Python packages campaign to Gleaming Pisces.</p>
<h2><a id="post-136761-_erks0at3jq2"></a>Poisoned Python Packages Campaign Technical Analysis and Detection</h2>
<p>While tracking down recent activity by Gleaming Pisces, we came across poisoned Python packages that various malicious fake personas uploaded to PyPI. These poisoned packages implemented an evasive infection chain to avoid detection and eventually downloaded a Linux RAT onto the infected endpoints. <a href="https://vipyrsec.com/research/elf64-rat-malware/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">VIPYR Security</a> and <a href="https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s?__biz=MzUyMjk4NzExMA%3D%3D&amp;mid=2247499462&amp;idx=1&amp;sn=7cc55f3cc2740e8818648efbec21615f&amp;chksm=f9c1cdcfceb644d9a6f169ca81188a0e3ab4a9799437f6c57b71ede3ac6aab6d121dd023d42a&amp;scene=178&amp;cur_album_id=1955835290309230595" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Qihoo 360</a> reported on this activity in detail, specifically involving the following Python packages:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">real-ids</span> (versions 0.0.3 - 0.0.5)</li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">coloredtxt</span> (version 0.0.2)</li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">beautifultext</span> (version 0.0.1)</li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">minisound</span> (version 0.0.2)</li>
</ul>
<p>Our analysis determined that while Qihoo 360 also reported on Windows-related activities, those activities appear to be separate from the Linux and macOS campaigns. Further, we assess that the activity reported on by Qihoo 360 was performed by a different threat actor, in contrast to the Linux and macOS campaigns that we here connect to Gleaming Pisces.</p>
<p>The infection chain includes several poisoned Python packages that decode and execute encoded code. After Python installed and loaded the malicious package, a malicious piece of code eventually ran several bash commands to download the RAT, modifying its permissions and executing it.</p>
<p>Figure 1 below shows the infection chain and the prevention of PondRAT by Cortex XDR.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136764" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136764" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136764" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-323365-136761-1.png" alt="Diagram illustrating a cybersecurity threat involving the Linux PondRAT malware in the Cortex XDR interface. The flowchart includes the use of commands like 'sh', 'chmod', and 'curl' on a Linux system. There is also a pane of alert details. " width="900" height="624" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-323365-136761-1.png 1483w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-323365-136761-1-635x440.png 635w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-323365-136761-1-1010x700.png 1010w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-323365-136761-1-768x532.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136764" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. The PondRAT malware prevented by Cortex XDR.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-136761-_z7xz96r7of1l"></a>Comparing PondRAT to Previous Gleaming Pisces Attributed Malware</h2>
<p>We found other malware by pivoting based on code similarities to PondRAT, as well as to previously conducted research and attribution to Gleaming Pisces. Figure 2 below depicts a summary of these similarities.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136766" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136766" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136766" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-326739-136761-2.png" alt="Image showing a flowchart related to cybersecurity threats associated with different operating systems. It illustrates the relationships between PondRAT and POOLRAT and the differences between the macOS and Linux systems. The flowchart begins with poisoned Python packages. " width="900" height="658" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-326739-136761-2.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-326739-136761-2-602x440.png 602w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-326739-136761-2-957x700.png 957w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-326739-136761-2-768x562.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-326739-136761-2-1536x1124.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136766" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Similarities between the malware we found and other malware previously attributed to Gleaming Pisces.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-136761-_p7awg1vl6cle"></a>Code Similarities between PondRAT and Kupayupdate_stage2</h3>
<p>In their recently published research, <a href="https://vipyrsec.com/research/elf64-rat-malware/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">VIPYR Security</a> analyzed the code of a Linux RAT (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">973f7939ea03fd2c9663dafc21bb968f56ed1b9a56b0284acf73c3ee141c053c</span>) that was an unknown at the time, which we now identify as the Linux variant of PondRAT. Gleaming Pisces’ operators did not strip the code, meaning the function names remained as the threat actor initially named them.</p>
<p>When we examined this RAT's main function, we saw that it contained calls to two different functions: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">FConnectProxy</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AcceptRequest</span>:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><strong>FConnectProxy</strong></span>: This function handles the connection to the C2 server. It sets up the URI and parameters of the HTTP requests.</li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><strong>AcceptRequest</strong></span>: This function parses and decrypts commands from the C2 server and is responsible for receiving and executing commands from their remote operators.</li>
</ul>
<p>Back in 2021, <a href="https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/analysis-reports/ar21-048d" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CISA reported</a> about another AppleJeus attack wave called Kupay Wallet. CISA identified a macOS RAT named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">kupayupdate_stage2</span> (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">91eaf215be336eae983d069de16630cc3580e222c427f785e0da312d0692d0fd</span>) that was used as the final payload of this wave.</p>
<p>Upon analyzing the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">kupayupdate_stage2</span> RAT for macOS, we noticed that the malware’s functions were also not stripped. When examining its code, we observed several similarities to the Linux RAT. This included the function names <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">FConnectProxy</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AcceptRequest</span>, and similar code execution flow.</p>
<p>Figure 3 shows these similarities below.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136768" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136768" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136768" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-330564-136761-3.png" alt="Two screenshots, side by side, of code for &quot;PondRAT&quot; on both MacOS (left) and Linux (right) platforms, highlighting functions such as &quot;FConnectProxy&quot; and &quot;AcceptRequest&quot;. The MacOS version includes command usages like usleep. Text is color-coded to differentiate commands, functions, and values." width="900" height="459" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-330564-136761-3.png 2029w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-330564-136761-3-786x401.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-330564-136761-3-1372x700.png 1372w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-330564-136761-3-768x392.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-330564-136761-3-1536x784.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136768" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Method names and execution flow similarities of the new Linux RAT and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">kupayupdate_stage2</span> RAT.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The next step in our analysis was comparing both of the RATs' <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AcceptRequest</span> functions. We noticed both variants use the same command numerical IDs and similar method names.</p>
<p>Figure 4 below shows that these functions are almost identical, including the command numerical IDs.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136770" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136770" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136770" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-333876-136761-4.png" alt="Two panels of computer code side by side. On the left is the PondRAT macOS sample and on the right is the PondRAT Linux sample. Various elements are highlighted in red boxes to show the similarities between the two. " width="600" height="609" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-333876-136761-4.png 1142w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-333876-136761-4-434x440.png 434w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-333876-136761-4-690x700.png 690w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-333876-136761-4-768x779.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136770" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. Comparison of both RATs’ <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AcceptRequest</span> function.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-136761-_ufnrnsdfihu2"></a>Shared Encryption Key</h3>
<p>While looking into the encryption method of PondRAT, we noticed that the key used for encrypting output sent back to the server was the following string:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">wLqfM]%wTx`~tUTbw&gt;R^#yG5R(3C:;.</span></li>
</ul>
<p>When we compared this key to the one used by <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">kupayupdate_stage2</span>, we noticed it was the same. Figure 5 shows the shared key below.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136772" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136772" style="width: 857px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136772 size-full" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-337138-136761-5.png" alt="Screenshot of computer code in an editor, featuring lines of data type and variable declarations in green text, with some numerical values highlighted in red." width="857" height="96" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-337138-136761-5.png 857w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-337138-136761-5-786x88.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-337138-136761-5-768x86.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 857px) 100vw, 857px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136772" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">kupayupdate_stage2</span> encryption key.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-136761-_ep0rq1advbdd"></a>PondRAT MacOS Variants Analysis</h3>
<p>Following the aforementioned findings, we pivoted and retrieved additional samples of PondRAT’s macOS variant that shared the same encryption key. We found a macOS sample that was <a href="https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s?__biz=MzUyMjk4NzExMA%3D%3D&amp;mid=2247499462&amp;idx=1&amp;sn=7cc55f3cc2740e8818648efbec21615f&amp;chksm=f9c1cdcfceb644d9a6f169ca81188a0e3ab4a9799437f6c57b71ede3ac6aab6d121dd023d42a&amp;scene=178&amp;cur_album_id=1955835290309230595" target="_blank" rel="noopener">previously attributed</a> to be a part of the poisoned Python packages campaign and an additional AppleJeus-related macOS RAT.</p>
<h4><a id="post-136761-_9srja215ofx8"></a>os_helper</h4>
<p>After analyzing the additional macOS samples that shared the same encryption key, we noticed that one of the samples, a Mach-O multi-arch binary file (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">bfd74b4a1b413fa785a49ca4a9c0594441a3e01983fc7f86125376fdbd4acf6b</span>), was using the same infrastructure as the Linux variant of PondRAT.</p>
<p>Since multi-arch binary files for macOS support both Intel and ARM architectures, this sample contained two other Mach-O binaries. These were compiled for x64 and ARM accordingly, as expected.</p>
<p>The two dropped binaries share the same code (function names and encryption key) with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">kupayupdate_stage2</span> as the Linux variant of PondRAT. Based on the apparent code similarities and the shared submitted name <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">os_helper</span>, we assess it was also delivered as the final poisoned Python packages campaign payload. Additionally, these macOS variants used the same C2 (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">jdkgradle[.]com</span>) as the Linux variant.</p>
<p>Figure 6 below depicts how Cortex XDR prevented the macOS malware execution.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136774" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136774" style="width: 500px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136774" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-340017-136761-6.png" alt="Alert details interface from Cortex XDR featuring a medium severity alert titled 'os_helper' with the status 'Prevented (Blocked)' indicated by a pink and white triangular warning icon with a shield in the center, connected to a circular icon below." width="500" height="507" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-340017-136761-6.png 556w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-340017-136761-6-434x440.png 434w" sizes="(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136774" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. The execution of the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">os_helper</span> macOS malware prevented by Cortex XDR.</figcaption></figure>
<h4><a id="post-136761-_as3qnnvhv37z"></a>AppleJeus-Related MacOS Variant</h4>
<p>Another macOS sample (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cbf4cfa2d3c3fb04fe349161e051a8cf9b6a29f8af0c3d93db953e5b5dc39c86</span>) we found during pivoting that shared the same encryption key was configured to use <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">rebelthumb[.]net</span> as the C2 server. <a href="https://www.volexity.com/blog/2022/12/01/buyer-beware-fake-cryptocurrency-applications-serving-as-front-for-applejeus-malware/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Volexity reported</a> that this domain was part of the AppleJeus campaign back in 2022. This finding further strengthens our attribution of this campaign to Gleaming Pisces.</p>
<h2><a id="post-136761-_64gvx5hu32sk"></a>The Connection between PondRAT and Gleaming Pisces’ POOLRAT</h2>
<p>During our analysis, we found one more difference between the two PondRAT Linux and macOS variants, aside from being compiled for different OS types. The Linux variant implemented a new <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SendPost</span> function by using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">libcurl</span> library while using the file path <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/tmp/xweb_log.md</span> as the error log for failed connection attempts to the C2 server.</p>
<p>Searching for files with similar behavior, we identified two more relevant samples that belonged to a Linux RAT exhibiting this trait. We identified this RAT as the Linux variant of POOLRAT.</p>
<h3><a id="post-136761-_f7du1xz5k42w"></a>What Is POOLRAT?</h3>
<p>In a <a href="https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/analysis-reports/ar21-048e" target="_blank" rel="noopener">2021 report</a>, CISA identified a macOS RAT dubbed <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">prtspool</span> (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">5e40d106977017b1ed235419b1e59ff090e1f43ac57da1bb5d80d66ae53b1df8</span>), used as the final payload in one of the AppleJeus (CoinGoTrade) attack waves. <a href="https://cloud.google.com/blog/topics/threat-intelligence/3cx-software-supply-chain-compromise/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Mandiant's analysis</a> of the 3CX supply chain attack also mentioned this RAT family. They reported that attackers used the POOLRAT malware to compromise 3CX’s macOS build environment.</p>
<p>ESET has also identified similarities between POOLRAT and a backdoor called <a href="https://www.welivesecurity.com/2023/04/20/linux-malware-strengthens-links-lazarus-3cx-supply-chain-attack/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">BADCALL for Linux</a>, also attributed to Gleaming Pisces. Figure 7 below shows the execution prevention of the POOLRAT macOS backdoor.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136776" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136776" style="width: 500px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136776" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-342903-136761-7.png" alt="Alert details interface of Cortex XDR, showing a medium severity alert which was prevented and blocked. The interface includes tags for DOM and security, and is highlighted in a pink and white color scheme with a triangular warning icon." width="500" height="507" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-342903-136761-7.png 556w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-342903-136761-7-434x440.png 434w" sizes="(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136776" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. The execution of the POOLRAT macOS malware prevented by Cortex XDR.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-136761-_8japlwo3jaeu"></a>The Linux Variants of POOLRAT</h3>
<p>The newly discovered Linux variants of POOLRAT (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">5c907b722c53a5be256dc5f96b755bc9e0b032cc30973a52d984d4174bace456</span>, SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">f3b0da965a4050ab00fce727bb31e0f889a9c05d68d777a8068cfc15a71d3703</span>) exhibit several notable similarities to its macOS counterpart (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">prtspool</span>). According to our analysis, we conclude that they are variants of the macOS POOLRAT rather than a new piece of malware.</p>
<p>The Linux and macOS versions use an identical function structure for loading their configurations, featuring similar method names and functionality. Additionally, the method names in both variants are strikingly similar, and the strings are almost identical. Lastly, the mechanism that handles commands from the C2 is nearly identical.</p>
<p>Figure 8 compares the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">LoadConfig</span> method of POOLRAT’s macOS and Linux variants.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136778" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136778" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136778" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-345635-136761-8.png" alt="Two side-by-side screenshots displaying code differences between POOLRAT Linux and POOLRAT MacOS. Each panel shows a programming script on a black background. Select areas are highlighted in red boxes to show the similarities between the two. " width="700" height="396" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-345635-136761-8.png 1404w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-345635-136761-8-777x440.png 777w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-345635-136761-8-1236x700.png 1236w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-345635-136761-8-768x435.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136778" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Comparison of the LoadConfig function between POOLRAT for macOS and POOLRAT for Linux.</figcaption></figure>
<p>These similarities in configuration and command handling suggest that the Linux versions are adaptations of the original macOS malware, justifying their classification as variants of POOLRAT.</p>
<p>Figure 9 below compares the main functionality of both of the variants.</p>
<figure id="attachment_136780" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-136780" style="width: 554px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-136780" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-348282-136761-9.png" alt="A screenshot displaying two side-by-side panels of code in a text editor. Each panel shows sections of C programming language, specifically focusing on switch statements managing various case operations related to configuration and setup functions. The code includes comments and function calls. The left panel is POOLRAT for Linux and the right panel id POOLRAT for macOS. " width="554" height="900" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-348282-136761-9.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-348282-136761-9-271x440.png 271w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/word-image-348282-136761-9-431x700.png 431w" sizes="(max-width: 554px) 100vw, 554px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-136780" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Comparison between POOLRAT for macOS and POOLRAT for Linux.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-136761-_ijz2spey3wa0"></a>PondRAT: The Lighter Version of POOLRAT</h2>
<p>When analyzing PondRAT samples, we found that the command handler had similarities to POOLRAT.</p>
<p>PondRAT has a straightforward set of commands that give the attacker the following capabilities:</p>
<ul>
<li>Uploading and downloading files</li>
<li>Checking an implant’s status to confirm if it is active</li>
<li>Instructing the implant to pause operations for a specified duration (“sleep”)</li>
<li>Executing commands (with an option to either retrieve their output or not)</li>
</ul>
<p>As the functionality of PondRAT is similar yet more limited than POOLRAT, we assess that PondRAT is a lighter version of POOLRAT. Table 1 below compares the commands implemented in POOLRAT and PondRAT.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>POOLRAT Commands</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>PondRAT Commands</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>Description</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MSG_Up</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MsgUp</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Download a file from the C2 server.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MSG_Down</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MsgDown</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Upload a file to the C2 Server.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MSG_Cmd</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MsgCmd</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Execute a command and retrieve the output.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MSG_Run</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MsgRun</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Execute a command and don’t retrieve the output.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MSG_ReadConfig</span></td>
<td></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Read the configuration file and send it to the C2.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MSG_WriteConfig</span></td>
<td></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Write a new configuration file.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MSG_SecureDel</span></td>
<td></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Delete a file.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MSG_Dir</span></td>
<td></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">List a directory.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MSG_Test</span></td>
<td></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Attempt to connect to an IPv4 address. </span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MSG_SetPath</span></td>
<td></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Change the current working directory.</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Table 1. Comparison between POOLRAT and PondRAT commands.</p>
<h2><a id="post-136761-_2qdstc8yyfzj"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>We’ve examined the poisoned Python packages campaign and its ties to the North Korean Gleaming Pisces APT group. Our analysis of the Linux variant of PondRAT, which was dropped as the final payload in this campaign, revealed significant similarities to malware attributed to Gleaming Pisces (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">kupayupdate_stage2</span>).</p>
<p>Furthermore, our investigation uncovered that PondRAT shares code similarities with POOLRAT, malware that was also previously attributed to Gleaming Pisces. The evidence of additional Linux variants of POOLRAT showed that Gleaming Pisces has been enhancing its capabilities across both Linux and macOS platforms.</p>
<p>The weaponization of legitimate-looking Python packages across multiple operating systems poses a significant risk to organizations. Such attacks pose a great risk because they can easily remain under the radar and pose detection challenges. Successful installation of malicious third-party packages can result in malware infection that compromises an entire network.</p>
<h2><a id="post-136761-_x29e04nm47d6"></a>Protections and Mitigations</h2>
<p>For Palo Alto Networks customers, our products and services provide the following coverage associated with this group.</p>
<p><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>Cortex XDR</strong></a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xsiam" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>XSIAM</strong></a> help detect user and credential-based threats by analyzing user activity from multiple data sources, including the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Endpoints</li>
<li>Network firewalls</li>
<li>Active Directory</li>
<li>Identity and access management solutions</li>
<li>Cloud workloads</li>
</ul>
<p>Cortex XDR and XSIAM build behavioral profiles of user activity over time with machine learning. By comparing new activity to past activity, peer activity and the expected behavior of the entity, Cortex XDR and XSIAM help detect anomalous activity indicative of credential-based attacks.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks also offers the following protections related to the attacks discussed in this post:</p>
<ul>
<li>Helps prevent the execution of known malicious malware and execution of unknown malware by using <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/subscriptions/threat-prevention" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>Behavioral Threat Protection</strong></a> and machine learning based on the Local Analysis module.</li>
<li>Cortex XDR Pro and XSIAM help <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr/cortex-xdr-analytics-alert-reference/cortex-xdr-analytics-alert-reference/analytics-alerts-by-required-data-source" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>detect post-exploit activity</strong></a>, including credential-based attacks, with behavioral analytics.</li>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/ngfw" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>Next-Generation Firewall</strong></a> with the <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-threat-prevention/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>Advanced Threat Prevention</strong></a> security subscription can help block the malware C2 traffic via the following Threat Prevention signature: <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=86805" target="_blank" rel="noopener">86805</a>.</li>
<li>The <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/resources/datasheets/advanced-wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>Advanced WildFire</strong></a> machine learning models and analysis techniques have been reviewed and updated in light of these new PondRAT and POOLRAT variants. Multiple products in the Palo Alto Networks portfolio leverage Advanced WildFire to provide coverage against both PondRAT and POOLRAT variants and other threats.</li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you might have been impacted or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>Unit 42 Incident Response team</strong></a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>EMEA: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>APAC: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings, including file samples and indicators of compromise, with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>Cyber Threat Alliance</strong></a>.</p>
<h2>Additional Resources</h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/threat-assessment-north-korean-threat-groups-2024/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Threat Assessment: North Korean Threat Groups</a> – Unit 42, Palo Alto Networks</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-136761-_ydqdbjg0dngh"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h2>
<p><strong>PondRAT Linux variant</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">973f7939ea03fd2c9663dafc21bb968f56ed1b9a56b0284acf73c3ee141c053c</span></li>
</ul>
<p><strong>PondRAT macOS variant</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0b5db31e47b0dccfdec46e74c0e70c6a1684768dbacc9eacbb4fd2ef851994c7</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">3c8dbfcbb4fccbaf924f9a650a04cb4715f4a58d51ef49cc75bfcef0ac258a3e</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">bce1eb513aaac344b5b8f7a9ba9c9e36fc89926d327ee5cc095fb4a895a12f80</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">bfd74b4a1b413fa785a49ca4a9c0594441a3e01983fc7f86125376fdbd4acf6b</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cbf4cfa2d3c3fb04fe349161e051a8cf9b6a29f8af0c3d93db953e5b5dc39c86</span></li>
</ul>
<p><strong>PondRAT C2s</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">jdkgradle[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">rebelthumb[.]net</span></li>
</ul>
<p><strong>POOLRAT Linux variant</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">f3b0da965a4050ab00fce727bb31e0f889a9c05d68d777a8068cfc15a71d3703</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">5c907b722c53a5be256dc5f96b755bc9e0b032cc30973a52d984d4174bace456</span></li>
</ul>
<p><strong>POOLRAT C2s</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">www.talesseries[.]com/write.php</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">rgedist[.]com/sfxl.php</span></li>
</ul>
      
              </div>

			</div> 
              <div class="be__post-nav">
    <a class="prev" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="gleaming-pisces-applejeus-poolrat-and-pondrat:article-nav:Threat Research Center">

    </a>
